title: Le Chatelier's Principle — Equilibrium Shifts
instructions: Use a reversible reaction system to observe how changes in concentration, temperature, and pressure affect chemical equilibrium. Recommended system: N₂O₄(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g) (colourless ⇌ brown).
steps: Seal an N₂O₄/NO₂ mixture in two identical syringes at room temperature. Note the brown colour intensity (proportional to [NO₂]).
Compress syringe A to half its volume (increase pressure). Observe colour change and compare to syringe B.
Cool syringe B in ice water (lower temperature). Compare colour to syringe A at room temperature.
Heat syringe A in warm water (40°C). Observe and record colour intensity change.
Add a small amount of NO₂ gas to a third syringe (increase [NO₂]). Observe equilibrium shift.
For each perturbation, predict the shift direction using Le Chatelier's principle, then verify with observation.
expected_outcome: Increased pressure → lighter colour (equilibrium shifts left to fewer moles of gas). Lower temperature → lighter colour (exothermic forward reaction shifts right, producing more N₂O₄). Increased [NO₂] → initially darker, then equilibrium shifts left.
self_check_rubric: Did you correctly predict the direction of equilibrium shift for each perturbation?
Did compressing the syringe reduce the brown colour (shift toward N₂O₄)?
Did cooling produce a lighter colour (more N₂O₄ formed)?
Can you explain each observation using Le Chatelier's principle?
Did you record quantitative colour intensity estimates for comparison?
